awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Ensuring robustness of communication between networked energy harvesting nodes
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar energy, ambient radio frequency energy, and mechanical vibrations, among others, provide opportunities for energy harvesting from the environment. Typically, it is feasible to store some of the harvested energy in a rechargeable local battery for future use.  Energy harvesting devices are therefore expected to soon play a major role as components of networks monitoring critical infrastructure, such as transportation networks and the smart grid. This development is also synergistic with the growth of the Internet of Things, with the number of devices connected to the network being two orders of magnitude more than what we have today. The development of energy harvesting in the context of critical infrastructure technologies is of central importance to the national interest and its development in the context of the Internet of Things offers profound benefits to society. The educational component of this project includes training graduate students, exposing undergraduate students to research, and transitioning the results of the research to core graduate and undergraduate courses.

The research in this project addresses the fundamental communications challenges posed by energy harvesting sensing networks in both the context of monitoring critical infrastructure and the Internet of Things. The research develops systematic techniques to design communication networks of sensing energy harvesting nodes that are robust to the variations in the energy harvesting process. The appropriate models to use depend on the relation between the time scale of the energy harvesting and the time scales inherent to the physical system being sensed, estimated, and controlled. This project studies both information theoretic and packet-drop models, corresponding respectively to fast or slow time scales for energy harvesting relative to the dynamics of the physical system.

por.por_cntn:
Solar energy, ambient radio frequency energy, and mechanical vibrations, among others, provide opportunities for energy harvesting from the environment. Typically, it is feasible to store some of the harvested energy in a rechargeable local battery for future use. Energy harvesting devices are therefore expected to play a major role as components of networks monitoring critical infrastructure, such as transportation networks and the smart grid. This development is also synergistic with the growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) since, with the number of devices connected to the network being a few orders of magnitude more than what we have today, it will be helpful for such devices to use energy harvesting techniques for their energy needs to avoid the need to frequently change the batteries.

The research in this project has addressed the fundamental communications challenges posed by energy harvesting sensing networks in both the context of monitoring critical infrastructure and IoT. We have focused on foundational issues in a model-based analytical framework, where the problem formulations have been guided by the specifics of applications deploying energy harvesting technologies.

A central feature of IoT deployments, partly driven by the limited and sporadic character of the available energy, is the delay-limited nature of the communication process. This means that the communication and security schemes need to pay particular attention to delay limits. To deal with this issue, as part of the research, we have made foundational contributions to the subject of one-shot information theory, which deals with communication schemes where there are delay limits. We have also made foundational contributions to one-shot secret key generation, with the same kind of motivation in view.

A central feature of many energy harvesting environments is the unpredictability of the pattern of the available energy from the enviroment. In order to improve the predictability of the available energy at the sensor (or agent in an IoT environment) it is necessary to develop estimation schemes that can provide good estimates of available energy without having a good model for the statistics of its availability. To address this issue we have made foundational contributions to the subject of calibrated learning, which studies precisely this sort of question, using a game theoretic framework.

Sensor networks in critical infrastructure often need to work together as a distributed agent to achieve monitoring tasks, which may also be potentially needed against adversaries attempting to attack the infrastructure. To perform such tasks well it is necessary to hedge against the options of the adversary, which requires the deployment of randomized strategies, for which it is necessary to generate common randomness in a distributed way. To do this in a delay-limited environment requires the study of sequential schemes for the generation of joint distributions across a network. As part of the research, we have made foundational contributions in this direction.
